results.headline: Another Dickens Orphan, Still Seeking More
results.summary_short: Mike Newell’s new version of “Great Expectations” features supporting work by Ralph Fiennes and Helena Bonham Carter.

results.headline: Old Friends Make a Deal and Try to Avoid the Devil
results.summary_short: John Sayles’s noirish thriller “Go for Sisters” travels deep into the worlds of various sorts of gangsters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go For Sisters

results.headline: Seeking a Gateway to a Passport in Seattle
results.summary_short: In “Finding Mr. Right,” the pregnant mistress of a rich man leaves China for Seattle, where she finds a new, unexpected love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Mr. Right

results.headline: It Couldn’t Be Dad, Could It?
results.summary_short: In “Blood and Ties,” a young woman wonders if her father is about to get away with murder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hidamari no Kanojo

results.headline: A New Dog With Old Tricks
results.summary_short: “Billy & Buddy,” based on a comic strip by Jean Roba, features a cocker spaniel and French comedic noises.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Billy & Buddy

results.headline: Still Chasing That Elusive Tiara
results.summary_short: The comedy “Ass Backwards” centers on best friends who take a road trip to their hometown to claim a beauty pageant crown that eluded them in childhood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ass Backwards

results.headline: Filling the Gaps of a Checkered Childhood
results.summary_short: Jung Henin and Laurent Boileau’s “Approved for Adoption” is a documentary memoir of Mr. Henin, who was adopted by a Belgian family from South Korea.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Approved for Adoption

results.headline: The Making of an Immortal Movie
results.summary_short: George Romero’s “Night of the Living Dead,” which brought zombies to the screen, is the subject of the documentary “Birth of the Living Dead.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Birth of the Living Dead

results.display_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone
results.headline: Blooming, Languishing, Reviving
results.summary_short: “The Stone Roses: Made of Stone” looks at a British band with a future that went unfulfilled.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stone Roses: Made of Stone

results.headline: Romantic Comedy: Imbibe in Moderation
results.summary_short: In “A Case of You,” a struggling writer remakes himself into the perfect match for the woman he has his eye on.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Case of You

results.headline: Making a Home for Pakistani Runaways
results.summary_short: The documentary “These Birds Walk” chronicles a humanitarian’s efforts to help street children in Karachi, Pakistan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of These Birds Walk

results.headline: The Politics of Acoustic Guitars
results.summary_short: “Musicwood,” a documentary by Maxine Trump, examines the thicket of issues that pit Native Americans in Alaska against the makers of acoustic guitars.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Musicwood

results.headline: A Writer Who’s Beat in Search of a Refuge
results.summary_short: Michael Polish’s film “Big Sur” is based on Jack Kerouac’s visits to that coastal California region, where he fled the literary success that followed the publication of “On the Road.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Sur

results.headline: A Little Shop of Possibilities
results.summary_short: “Sweet Dreams” looks at how a Brooklyn ice cream company helped a group of Rwandan women start their own business.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweet Dreams

results.headline: The Hidden Meaning of Films, Take 2
results.summary_short: “The Pervert’s Guide to Ideology” is the second critical analysis of what values the movies are really imparting, by the philosopher Slavoj Zizek.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pervert's Guide to Ideology

results.headline: Tattoos and Bluegrass Music in the Wilds of Belgium
results.summary_short: In “The Broken Circle Breakdown,” directed by Felix van Groeningen, a Belgian couple are buffeted by the news that their daughter has cancer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Broken Circle Breakdown

results.headline: 50 Years Ago, That’s the Way It Was
results.summary_short: “One PM Central Standard Time” recalls Nov. 22, 1963, as Walter Cronkite delivered the news.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One PM Central Standard Time

results.headline: The Private Heartaches of a People’s Princess
results.summary_short: Naomi Watts portrays the Princess of Wales in a film that revisits her affair with a Pakistani heart surgeon, based on Kate Snell’s book “Diana: Her Last Love.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diana

results.headline: Taking On Broncos and a Plague
results.summary_short: Matthew McConaughey stars as an unlikely advocate for patients with H.I.V., taking his treatment into his own hands in “Dallas Buyers Club.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dallas Buyers Club

results.headline: Outdistancing Suicide, Papa’s Family Curse
results.summary_short: In a Barbara Kopple documentary, Mariel Hemingway discusses the struggle against a genetic predisposition to mental illness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Running from Crazy
